Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I dwell in the rural parts, in Michigan where the land stretches out between farms and them little tourist towns that dot the shores like broken shells. Aint no big stores here. No chains neither. Just empty roads that lead to somewhere else if you got the mind to follow them.

The waters though. The waters hold everything together like God's own hands cupped around this piece of earth. Lake Michigan vast and grey to one side and Lake Charlevoix to the other, both of them ancient and deep and full of secrets. Beaches everywhere you turn, sand and stone waiting for feet to press their memories into them.

The houses stand apart from each other like old men who've learned the value of distance. Each one different, each one carrying its years in different ways. Some got new faces put on them, others wear their age like medals. Most got basements you can see right from the street, dug deep into the earth like root cellars waiting for storms that aint come yet. The aluminum siding gone silver and dull in the sun, colors faded but still holding on. Every shade you could name and some you couldn't.

Yards spread out wide enough for dreams to grow. Trampolines standing like black circles against the sky, swing sets creaking their metal songs in the wind. Gardens where people plant hope every spring, fences holding dogs that bark at shadows.

These are working people's homes. The kind of folks who know what calluses mean and what time the sun comes up. Children run wild in the streets like scattered birds, their voices carrying on the wind. Dogs and their people making their daily rounds, wheels turning on pavement, everybody knowing everybody else's business and keeping track of strangers.

You see someone cooking meat over fire, they raise a hand. Someone walking their dog from three streets over, they nod like they've known you all their life. The grass stays cut, the leaves don't pile up when autumn comes calling. Everything trimmed and neat but not proud about it.

Aint beautiful in the way that makes people stop and stare, but beautiful in the way that makes them want to stay. Quiet settles here like dust, and safety wraps around you like an old quilt. Got the sheriff's office walking distance away, and the jail right there with it like they was born twins. Health department too, and the place where they sort through what people throw away, trying to make something new from something old.

You can hear the ballgames echo across the evening, voices calling out names like they was reading from some holy book. Planes come and go from the little airport, their engines growling at the sky. Ice cream place aint far, and downtown waits just beyond that. Eight blocks to the park where children ride their bikes like they was chasing summer itself.

This here's a good place. A right place. The kind of place where the world makes sense if you let it.

They built it all the same. Row after row of houses standing like sentries in the desert sun, each one a mirror of its neighbor, each yard a testament to some unseen authority's grip on order. The HOA they called it. Association of homeowners though none seemed to own anything but debt and obligation to sameness.

You drive in past the houses with their identical patches of grass, stones laid just so, driveways cut short like stillborn roads. Trees no taller than a man dot the landscape at measured intervals. Two-car garages stand silent, waiting. The concrete beneath your wheels still fresh and unmarked by time or weather, as if the earth itself feared to crack it.

No mailboxes stand sentinel before these homes. They cluster instead at street's end like metal soldiers in formation, each with its tiny brass key and lock. Above them two larger boxes for the packages that come. Modern life delivered in cardboard and tape.

The neighborhood sits at the city's edge where civilization meets wilderness in an uneasy truce. Land stretches vast and empty save for the pools they built, fenced and chlorinated against nature's intrusion. Walking trails wind through like veins in living tissue, carrying people and their dogs in endless circuits.

The old ones live here mostly. Retirees who've traded their years for security and sameness. Some younger folk too, with briefcases and tired eyes, but they're fewer. All watch each other's homes with the vigilance of prison guards, though there are no prisoners here save perhaps themselves.

The city beyond pulses with its own life. One mall stands like a concrete monolith, neither grand nor humble. Fifteen minutes by car in any direction leads to commerce - stores stacked with organic produce at prices that would shame a thief, or bare-shelved outlets where fluorescent lights hum their discount hymns over near-empty aisles.

They built it all to last, this neighborhood. Built it safe and clean and predictable as sunrise. The pools stay blue, the trails stay clear, the houses stay the same. And if sometimes in the night you hear the desert calling from beyond the development's edge, well, that's what walls are for.

First I heard tell of the place was through some voices speaking of the vanished, crackling through the ether like ancient spirits. Strange thing. Most dwellings thereabouts cost a thousand or more in paper dollars each moon cycle. None I knew had heard such tales. Maybe it's the weight of living that does it. Some friends weep in their beds come nightfall. Everything costs dear now but we learned the way of it. You come to know the smell of secondhand things, dust-covered playthings and clothes gone yellow with age. The nose grows dull with the years. Might be the tobacco. Might be you just stop noticing after time enough passes.

But the fleamarket abides. Childhood dies in the smell of old paper stacked on dead pianos. The scent works its way into leather like original sin, no washing gets it out. Three stores dealing in cast-offs within walking distance. Start at the far end and you can walk through two charity shops, a library full of forgotten words, a place selling rare books, and a shop of curiosities. Downtown swells with metal and flesh each morning but the thrift stores keep their silence like tombs. No matter the parade outside, inside stays quiet as a church. Good place to lose yourself. More folks come each year, more machines too. They call it progress. Some great digital empire planted its flag here, spreading like kudzu across the land. Makes me think of New York. Everyone carrying their own burden, asking nothing of nobody. A body can keep to themselves, quiet-like, and ain't nobody going to disturb that peace. Not like down South where concern passes for caring. Folk here don't dig into your business none.

You can keep your walls up long as you please and the city just rolls past like the tide. Place has life though. Got a piano player next door, two trying to be singers up above. Less strangers sharing walls than a kind of family. We gather when need calls, mark births and deaths together, help each other through the dark times. Lucky, I reckon, to have landed here. Neighbors treat me fair and I do the same. Clean up after myself, share food when I can. We pass mail back and forth like peace offerings. Good to see them and I figure they feel the same. Living in this great concrete maze of modernity but it's folk like these make me think I ain't wasted my life after all.

The town sits like a tired dog at the edge of the metropolis, neither city nor country, a place where the shadows of prosperity fall long and dark across the eastern streets where we make our home. Here the houses stand weathered and wanting, passed from hand to hand like worn dollar bills, their paint peeling in the summer heat and winter cold alike. But there aint no meanness here. Folk nod and speak when you pass. They carry their poverty like old coats, worn but dignified.

Violence comes sometimes like a thief in the night. Gunshots have torn the darkness. Blood has marked these streets. The neighbors boy, not more than twenty, fell outside MacGregor's Bar last winter, his life seeping into black asphalt while music played inside. We've lost nothing save what the night people take from porches, small things left forgotten in the gloaming.

The poison that runs through the veins of America runs here too. Fentanyl. A word like a death sentence. Bodies found in doorways and alleys, souls departed on wings of synthetic dreams. The town fights back with clinics and training, teaching the living how to pull back the dead.

The school stands like a fortress of hope. My boy goes there, different from the others but loved all the same. No child hungry, no child marked by the sins of poverty. The teachers move through the halls like guardians, their calling written in chalk dust and patience.

The town council men pour money into the western streets like water on parched earth. New pavement gleaming. Parks with fresh paint. While here in the east we watch and wait, our streets collecting pools of rain and forgotten promises.

Sixteen years we've lived here. The house aint much but it holds us. The walls know our voices. The floors remember our steps. Sometimes at night I stand on the porch and look west where the lights of the city proper paint the sky orange and purple. But this is home. This is where we'll stay until the darkness or the light takes us.

The neighborhood sits high upon the hill like some ancient acropolis, its buildings worn and weathered sentinels of time long past. My dwelling, seven stories of concrete and steel, stands watch over the old theater house across the way, and down the slope there's a place where folk gather in the summer heat to play at games of light and sound. They come in droves when the air is thick with evening warmth, queuing like pilgrims before some neon shrine.

The park lies northward, vast as any urban expanse might be in such a place. Great concrete walls ring it round, steps carved like the marks of some forgotten giant's ascent. When winter comes the homeless gather there, their temporary cities risen in neat rows along the walls, canvas homes strung together against the wet and cold. The rain comes more often than snow, brutal and unrelenting in the dark months, and these souls huddle close in the city's heart rather than scatter to the wild margins where death comes easier. They stay near the shelter where water runs clean and warm, where they might wash away the day's grime.

But it aint the old architecture nor the proud buildings that makes this place sing. It's the blood memory of the streets themselves. Hilltop they call it, once known coast to coast for its violence, its gangs, its darkness. Old timers still speak of government men coming through like locusts, badges gleaming, trying to scrub these streets clean. The stories persist, passed down like scripture, mother to child, stranger to stranger, reaching even outsiders like myself.

The people here, they tend their streets like gardens now, though others still name it rough country. White folks get warned away after dark, though that's just echoes of old fears, prejudices carved deep as the hill itself. Maybe it's my own darkness that lets me pass unmarked, or maybe the hill knows its own, knows who understands its pain, its history of division and fear in this supposed paradise of cultures mixed.

This much I know: these streets are home. Here I've walked in darkness and found only kindness - a coat offered against the cold, a door held open when rain fell like judgment, a stranger's eyes meeting mine in my lowest moments, pressing currency in my palm and speaking words of worth into my emptiness. Here among these broken sidewalks and tired buildings, I found my place in the world.

I came to this place in the summer before eighth grade commenced, when the air was thick and heavy like molasses and the streets lay empty save for the occasional wandering dog. Making friends dont come easy to a boy in a strange land but there were two others, one who dwelled two doors down and another who lived along the same stretch of asphalt, though both are gone now, scattered like leaves in an autumn wind. Their ghosts remain.

The houses stand two stories tall, uniform and patient, watching. The same folk who were here when I first arrived still abide, their presence as constant as the seasons. Children's voices carry on the warm air, their laughter echoing off vinyl siding and concrete driveways like some ancient ritual of youth. The neighborhood keeps its own counsel most days, quiet as a church mouse.

There's a park nearby, not more than a minute's walk through territory that feels both foreign and familiar. Basketball hoops stand sentinel over cracked courts where we played our games, the concrete witness to countless victories and defeats. Got my nose broke there once, catching an elbow in a football game, the blood bright and shocking against the grey pavement. But that's just one tale among many.

Now I take my cousin's young ones there, watch them climb and swing like small monkeys in a steel jungle. Their joy is pure and unfiltered, like light through clean glass. The park holds memories like a vessel holds water, some sweet, some bitter.

The neighborhood is a patchwork quilt of cultures, each square stitched tight against the other. Food from all corners of the earth can be found here - Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian - though nowadays folk summon their sustenance through glowing rectangles and waiting drivers. Fast food joints sprout like weeds along the roadside, and pizza parlors stand guard on every corner.

Stores line the streets like teeth in a jaw. Two pharmacies face each other across the asphalt like duelists, while the Jewel-Osco holds court nearby, its fluorescent kingdom a beacon in the Midwestern night. An Indian store stands apart, its shelves heavy with spices and secrets from across the ocean.

When I read of the tribulations others endure with their neighbors, of the small wars fought across property lines and the bitter feuds that poison communities like bad well water, I know I've been blessed. This place, for all its mundane facade, has been good to me. It has been home.

The college stands near where I make my home, and that's good enough. Rows of tired buildings line the streets, their facades weathered like old bones in the sun, with taverns and eateries scattered among them like wayward children. They renamed one of the bars. Made it costly. Still serves the same poison.

The people here exist in two tribes: scholars and the poor. All of them packed into these cheap dwellings like cattle in pens. Children too, countless of them, drawn to the schoolhouse that squats just beyond where the pavement ends. My neighbors are strangers and that's how it'll stay. They fill the halls with sweet smoke until management hung a plastic box that spits perfume across their door. A joke written in artificial pine.

Ancient buildings stand shoulder to shoulder, their insides gutted and remade while their faces tell tales of decades past. Down the road they've raised new apartments, raw wounds in the urban flesh, built quick and cheap but priced dear. A scam blessed by proximity to learning.

There's a place that serves food on paper, everything heated in boxes that hum. Across the way a gas station stands sentinel, its fluorescent glow a beacon for the desperate. The city came with their machines and tamed the road, laid new concrete like a clean blanket over old dirt. They planted grass in strips, as if nature could be parceled and contained.

Trees crowd my building like mourners at a wake. Some fell to the saw, their stumps testament to their passing. Behind us lies another street, meaner and darker, where concrete crumbles and buildings wear their poverty like badges. Crime blooms there like nightshade, though it spreads its seeds across to our side too. The people come and go like desert winds, leaving no trace.

But it suits me. My wallet stays full enough, and I can walk to what I need. The buses come regular as heartbeats, carrying us to market and town like modern day traders following ancient routes.

The duplexes stand like yellow sentinels in the dying light, white porches thrust forward like bleached bones, green metal roofs catching what's left of the sun. A cul-de-sac where people gather without purpose or plan, their children scrawling chalk prophecies on concrete while kites dance against clouds that billow white as cotton in late summer. Fields stretch out beyond the houses and trees rise up black against the sky like ancient guardians of some forgotten time.

Then the sirens came. They came with a wailing that spoke of something vast and terrible moving across the land. The dog, the small one, trembled against me in the porcelain tub while the big one paced and barked at shadows, refusing sanctuary. Outside the hail fell like God's own buckshot, pelting the earth with a fury that knew no mercy. The road steamed afterward like some great wounded beast, the temperature falling from ninety-two to seventy-five as if the world itself had caught fever and broken it.

The sun pierced the clouds and rain fell still, and there arose in the sky twin arcs of color like some divine covenant. People emerged from their shelters slow and cautious like creatures after flood. The women and children returned to their evening rituals, to their cooking and their playing, speaking in that slow southern drawl that flows like honey over warm bread.

Behind the houses lies a pond not meant for swimming and beyond that fields where deer move like ghosts in the morning mist. A bullfrog sings his ancient song at dawn, competing with roosters that crow their existence into the void. Forty minutes from Charlotte but it might as well be forty years from anywhere. A donkey brays in the gloaming, his voice carrying across fields that haven't changed since before men came to name them. The houses may look alike but inside they hold different stories, different sizes, different truths. Some small as prison cells, others sprawling like the fields themselves. Found this place like finding an arrowhead in freshly plowed earth, unexpected and precious in its own way.

Ten years now. Ten years in this place and the memories they come like ghosts in the night, haunting and pure. We came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, my sister and I and our parents who sought better things for us, better schools, better houses, things that folk called civilized. I wept then. The tears came unbidden like rain in summer storms.

The years passed as years do. Friends came. Enemies too. Neighbors remained strangers save for Mr. Glen and Dennis who lived beside us, their presence like old trees that had always been there. Mr. Glen wed again and we were there, all of us, watching the ceremony unfold like some ancient ritual. Ms. Veda in white, removing the garter, throwing it into the darkness where I caught it like some talisman of future promise. Marsharii danced with me that night. Never saw her after. The world takes what it takes.

The neighborhood stretches out like some labyrinth of asphalt and dreams. GPS now tells me where to go but in those days Kason and Curtis and I would wander like pilgrims through the streets, playing our games, living in that eternal present that only youth knows. The park became my sanctuary. Still is. Nature speaks there in tongues older than man. I practice with sticks bought from hardware stores, wooden swords, balance exercises like some warrior monk seeking enlightenment in the suburban wilderness.

Tennis courts and basketball hoops stand sentinel, unused now but waiting. My father and Mr. Graves taught us tennis in those days, working us until sweat ran like rivers down our backs. The memory sits there like a photograph yellowing at the edges.

There are more stories. There are always more stories. They live in the corners of memory, in the shadows of streetlights, in the quiet moments between heartbeats. And somewhere out there, beyond the horizon of now, better things wait. They always do.

The town aint much to look at. Just another spot on the map in South Carolina but it feeds more than its share. Johnston they call it and they paint their pride on the welcome sign declaring it Peach Capital of the World like some ancient proclamation. The land stretches out in plots of peach trees or cattle pasture, the houses set back from the road like afterthoughts in the vast expanse. Metal roofs gleam under the merciless summer sun, others wear crowns of gray shingle, all of them scattered like dice thrown across the countryside.

In the heart of it theres one stoplight swaying above a fourway crossing where commerce congregates in meager offerings. Three places to fill your belly: the Hong Kong run by a family who keeps to themselves, the Fiesta where Mexican music drifts through screendoors, and Garys where burgers sizzle on ancient grills. The pizza place died quiet-like some time back.

Maxwell and Halford Drug stands like a sentinel of older times, known more for its cherry cola than its medicines. The IGA charges dear for groceries and most folks make the pilgrimage to Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville, leaving the IGA for desperate purchases. The Dollar General draws them in like moths to flame, from sunup to sundown they come and go with their plastic bags of necessity.

A woman runs the furniture store called Possibilities, her name known to all, her two movers like disciples of comfort hauling sofas and beds across the county. Next door the pet groomer tends to the towns animals in a place called Clarks, washing and clipping and boarding them like some kind of domestic zookeeper.

The doctors both for man and beast keep their practices away from town center, small outposts of healing in the vastness. One school stands for the young ones but after fifth grade they scatter like seed to the next town over. No parks yet exist though they scratch at the earth now to make one, two and a half acres of promised recreation like some garden of Eden to draw new souls to this place.

Nothing much happens here. No picture shows or bowling alleys or gathering spots where youth might congregate. No playgrounds for the children or paths for dogs to walk. Just a town so small you might pass through it between blinks, like a dream half-remembered in the morning light.

We live where the asphalt runs between two highways in the Tennessee south, a place where cars pass like migrating birds, their metal wings catching the sun. The neighborhood stands quiet save for the mechanical drone of passing vehicles. People here stay. They root deep like the old trees that were here before the houses came. They work their yards in ancient rhythms, pushing mowers in endless circles, raking leaves that fall like brown rain.

The house sits corner-wise to the street, watching. Always watching. Four souls dwell within. Man, woman, two girls whose ages mark time like tree rings, eleven and fourteen winters gone. We know the mechanical beasts that prowl these streets, their engines singing familiar songs. When strange ones come we mark them, note them, watch them pass.

Walkers traverse the asphalt river, some with dogs that pull at their leads like conscience at the heart. Children pedal their wheeled contraptions, spinning circles in the dying light. We work from inside these walls, venturing out to play even when the sky weeps. The grill sends smoke signals from the wooden deck, meat-scent carrying on the wind like prayers.

The song of summer is the mower's growl, March through October, when the grass finally surrenders to the cold. Trees stand sentinel, their shadows pooling like old memories on the ground. Come autumn they shed their skin in brown drifts that we gather and burn, the smoke rising like souls to heaven. Winter comes seldom now, just the long slow death of fall stretching endless into spring.

The garage stands rear-guard, our front door like a forgotten tomb save for the rare knock that echoes through the halls. When the garage yawns open I work on the truck, metal on metal, grease-stained fingers turning wrenches while the neighborhood breathes around me. Holidays bring the strangers, kin-folk parking their mechanical steeds wherever asphalt offers quarter. Thanksgiving, Christmas, Mother's Day - they come and go like tides.

This place suits us well enough. If not for the river of cars flowing endless between the highways, it might be something close to perfect.

The desert stretches out like some vast and ancient thing, all dirt and emptiness, and we who live here know its true nature. Not like them others who come to visit and leave again. Brown is the color of everything here. When someone puts in grass you know they've sold their soul to the water company and there aint no coming back from that.

I came here in the nineties when the houses stood apart like sentinels in the waste, each one watching the other from afar. Now they've multiplied like some concrete pestilence but still the desert holds them at bay. The city grows like a cancer but that's the way of things everywhere now. Good folk and bad folk both live here same as anywhere else. My part's got old people, quiet types who mind their business and wave from their porches in the evening heat.

Chain stores is what we got. Food for Less. Smart and Final. The fancy stores don't come here. Won't come here. Construction's the blood that runs through this place, men building more and more houses in the emptiness like they're trying to fill up something that don't want filling. Makes me uneasy. I left the big city to get away from all that.

I work construction myself. Drywall and T-bar installation. My hands know the work like they know my own face.

The animals here, they're something else. Different creatures that God made special for this hardscrabble land. Lizards that look like the rocks they hide under. Bugs that could survive the end times. My young ones chase them around like it's some kind of holy mission. The desert's got its own kind of stark beauty that calls to certain folk. Makes them want to stay.

The county fair comes through sometimes. Brings lights and noise and people. Up in Wrightwood the mountains wear snow like white scarves. Down at the museum they keep pieces of the old world. Indian things. Bones from the ground. Artifacts from when this place was young. All of it telling some story about how we came to be here, though the desert itself remembers longer than any of us ever will.

The campus stretches out before me like some vast concrete plain, dormitories rising up from the earth like ancient monoliths. This here aint no ordinary neighborhood like them others might describe. No picket fences. No soccer moms. Just endless corridors of souls bound together in this academic purgatory.

The buildings stand testament to different tribes. Three kinds there are. First the apartments, stacked boxes of glass and steel where bodies pile two deep, four deep, sometimes more, floor upon floor like layers in some architectural cake of humanity. Twenty souls to a building near as I can reckon. Then there's them proper houses, scattered like afterthoughts across the grounds, where mostly old graduates hole up in twos and fours, clinging to some vestige of normalcy in this strange land. Last come the dormitories proper, great concrete behemoths swallowing hundreds whole, two to a cell save for them lucky few who managed solitude.

The people here, they come from everywhere and nowhere. All colors, all ages, all walks. The learned ones, the professors and such, they claim them standalone houses like territory markers. The young ones, fresh-faced and raw, they pack into them dorms like cattle. The older students, they take to them apartments, having earned some semblance of dignity in their time here.

Markets and stores dot the landscape like oases in this academic desert. Food halls serving up sustenance. School stores hawking overpriced cloth bearing the institution's mark. Grocers keeping us fed. Everything a body might need contained within these borders, like some self-sufficient colony cut off from the world beyond.

And there's the park. One single patch of green midst all this stone and steel. Kept clean by some unspoken law, watched over by all who call this place home. A sanctuary where all them diverse souls come to remember what the world beyond these walls feels like. Strange how such a place can become home, can become everything you know, everything you need.

No sidewalks here. The world tilts downward like God himself set it askew and my house stands sentinel at the peak where runners come to test themselves against the slope. They call it the workout hill. Just a name. Nothing more. The road beneath carries all who pass, its surface pocked and scarred like an old fighter's face. Above, the power lines hang like black rosary beads, patched and mended where storm and branch have done their violence. Their repairs a testament to man's endless war with weather.

The trees rise up everywhere. Evergreens tall as judgment. The people here hate them with a fury reserved for old enemies, cutting them down with mechanical precision, seeking always the water beyond. Houses stack themselves against the hill like wooden martyrs, their glass faces turned forever seaward, watching. At sunset the bay burns orange and gold as if lit from below by some ancient fire, though most days the clouds hang thick as wool and the light filters gray through the perpetual haze.

Moss claims everything here. It grows without permission or purpose, coating the world in velvet green. Left my truck standing a month and found it transformed, wrapped in a funeral shroud of vegetation that took hours to strip away.

No children here. Just old folks waiting out their days and dogs that roam like spirits through the streets, entering houses unbidden as if they owned them. Once found one standing in my living room like it had always been there, watching me with eyes older than sin.

Rabbits too, big as cats, digging at the earth like miners searching for gold. My cats hunt them with ancient efficiency, their instincts unchanged since the world was young. Birds wheel overhead - sparrows and hummingbirds small as thoughts, while hawks and eagles patrol until the crows drive them off like dark shepherds protecting their flock.

Down at the water's edge where the restaurants serve up the day's catch, there ain't much beach to speak of. Just rocks that men throw into the water as if casting away their sins. The bay stretches out narrow as a grave, the far shore visible even through the mist like a promise you can't quite keep.

Bensonhurst lay there like some vast concrete labyrinth, a place where the subway trains come screaming through the night like metal prophets. You'll find it sure enough. The city dont hide its wounds.

The streets pulse with a new blood now. Asian merchants have claimed their territory block by block, year by year, their storefronts blazing with neon signs in languages that dance like ancient runes. Supermarkets stand shoulder to shoulder, four within a stone's throw, their shelves heavy with goods strange and familiar. The laundromats hum their eternal song of spin cycles and steam.

But this aint no singular culture's domain. The neighborhood breathes with the mingled breath of a thousand histories, immigrants and their children and their children's children, all of them carrying their own particular darkness and light. The park stands renewed, a concrete paradise where children play at being children. Basketball courts stretch like connected graveyards, the thump of rubber on asphalt a heartbeat in the city's chest. Soccer fields spread green and wanting. The water fountain spits its offering to the summer gods while children dance in its spray.

Houses stand two deep mostly, families stacked like cordwood against the cold. The streets speak their own language. Music bleeds from passing cars, engines roar their defiance at the dawn. Night brings its own breed of citizen, carrying whatever darkness they've borrowed from the void. They'll take what aint theirs if you let them. Violence sleeps light here, like some coiled thing waiting for the wrong word or look.

The neighborhood wears its scars like medals. Package thieves prowl like coyotes, taking what the porches offer up. Dog waste lies in wait like small brown landmines, ignored by their makers despite whatever laws man has put forth to prevent such things. The city's rules mean little here where the concrete meets the sky.

Watch your step. Keep your eyes up. The city dont forgive carelessness.

Portland Oregon aint about what you think it is. It's about the weird and what weird means aint what you think neither. There's a sign painted up on some building that serves pizza and music and flesh and lord knows what else and it says Keep Portland Weird like some prayer or incantation against the future that's already come. Some folks'll tell you it's about remembering what was, back before the money came. Others'll say it's an invitation to come be strange in a place that dont mind strange. But weird aint what you think.

The Californians come with their money like locust clouds, building their glass towers toward a gray heaven that weeps nine months of the year. Still the weird persists. Not like acceptance exactly but like a tolerance for the intolerable. We got our Chinese goods same as anywhere. Got our yoga people and our coffee people and our business people in their pressed shirts moving through the streets like ghosts of some other civilization.

In my neighborhood the houses stand painted in colors that'd shame a Mexican carnival. Gardens grow wild along the walkways, herbs and flowers pressing up through cracks in the concrete like nature making its last stand. And there's the boxes. Just cardboard mostly, sometimes plastic, set out like offerings to unknown gods. People put their castoffs in em but there's something holy about it, like every box might hold some revelation meant just for you. Clothes mostly. Books. But sometimes treasure.

Some folks here'd rather do their stretching with goats - real goats mind you, not some metaphor - or watch men kick balls across a field while thousands scream. The rain comes down and the clouds hang low and the darkness gets in peoples heads. Makes em crazy sometimes. Makes em forget who they are. The addicted and the homeless congregate like pilgrims at some blighted shrine. The city tries to help em but it aint enough. Never is. The rest of us watch em, sometimes with pity, sometimes with hate, and in that we aint weird at all. Just human. Terribly human.

They stood there eternal. North. Silent witnesses to the sun's daily pilgrimage across the vault of heaven. A man could forget them in the mundane toil of his days but they remained. Unmoved. Unbound. Beyond the petty sufferings of men. And when the spirit grew weary they called out with voices that had no sound and in their presence the troubled soul found rest. Found strength enough to weather one more dawn.

The university lay in their shadow. Buildings of stone and brick where young minds sought knowledge or whatever simulacrum of it they could grasp. Ponds mirrored the sky. Trees older than any living memory spread their ancient limbs. But the mountains ruled over all like gods of stone.

The town spread below them like a supplicant. Cafes where students bent over books and machines drinking bitter draughts to ward off sleep. Downtown the old buildings stood shoulder to shoulder, their bricks weathered to colors no living hand had painted. Here the pulse of the city beat strong as any metropolis but it didnt last. Past the library the quiet returned like an old dog to its familiar bed. These two worlds existed side by side like some cosmic joke about the nature of man's aspirations.

Memories collected in the corners and alleyways like wind-blown leaves. Some sweet as summer wine shared with companions. Running through lamp-lit streets to catch pictures at the theater. Others bitter as medicine. The ponds at night. Two AM and the soul screaming questions at a universe that gave no answer. Watching lesser creatures live their ordained lives while purpose remained elusive as smoke.

Walking north past houses that seemed to hide behind their own pretensions. The sun painting the sky in colors that had no names. Palm trees swaying like supplicants at prayer. And there they stood. Mountains older than time itself breaking the horizon like the spine of some great beast. Speaking without voice. Teaching without words the meaning of endurance.

You'd walk past it and never know. Past the dead hulk of what was once a Whole Foods store, past the hotels where folk come and go like migratory birds in their seasons, there lies a world unknown. The buildings rise up like ancient monoliths, apartment complexes lined up careful and precise as bone fragments from some great beast laid out for study. First comes the one they speak of in whispers on the evening news, but we'll pass that by quick enough. Evil lives where it chooses and wears what face it will.

Beyond there stand three more, different somehow, like a secret kept from the town that built them. Across the way sits the college, quiet as a church on Monday, where young souls drift in with their paper cups and their dreams still clinging to their eyelids like morning dew. The gates groan their protest at each passing, and the traffic builds up like bile in the throat of progress while workers curse the dawn and the students who herald it.

Where the road ends another begins, and there's the park on one side and the bone menders on the other, their porch furniture bright as false teeth, ceiling fan turning slow and methodical as God's own timepiece. Children spin through the grass like bright human pinwheels while bees work their ancient profession among the roadside blooms. Old men walk their dogs and eye the skateboard kids like they're studying some new species of trouble, nodding to the young girls who cluster like starlings and speak in voices that carry secrets.

The strip mall squats beside it all, holding its trinity of commerce - raw fish and chlorine and painted nails all in a row like some strange sacrament of suburban life. The yogurt shop stands at the end, its windows collecting fingerprints of the young who gather there with their sugared cups and their vapors, performing their rituals of youth on wheeled boards while time stands still as it always has in these southern places, these forgotten corners where America dreams its small dreams and wakes to find them unchanged.

The houses stand like weathered sentinels. Some whole, some split asunder yet joined still in their aging frames, bearing witness to times past and times coming. A small patch of earth marks the front, a strip of concrete the side, testament to dreams that once coursed through the veins of a nation like fever. Dreams that now recede like shadows at dusk, though their skeletal forms remain, crying out in mute supplication to those who'd listen that all aint lost, not yet.

The people here carry less hope in their eyes than their fathers did. Grass grows wild where once it was tamed, yet automobiles still rest in driveways like sleeping beasts and children play their games, unknowing that their world is but a fraction of what exists beyond. The school stands like an ancient monolith, ninety years of youth passing through its halls, each generation leaving ghosts for the old to remember. Churches stand empty save for dust and memory while basketball courts pulse with life and motion.

Each house different yet carrying the same weight of years. The market, Super A they call it, run by Yemeni folk, perhaps the only Arabs for miles around. Black faces populate the streets, generations deep in the soil here. Wide streets where children play at football, pausing only when metal carriages pass through their games. Old timers speak of days when names and faces were known to all, when community wasn't just a word but a living thing.

Where once stood a temple to martial arts now stands a dispensary of modern medicine, Hollywood's dreams having moved on to other things. The picture house remains, showing shadows of the past at cut-rate prices, shunned by the young but embraced by the old who find solace in its dimmed confines. A single highway cuts through like a concrete river, its tributaries emptying into neighboring towns, denied entrance here by elders who saw in its coming the death of something precious.

They speak now of mascots for the new school rising from the earth. Some say a mechanical man with a country drawl and pioneer dwelling would suit. Perhaps they're right. Perhaps not. The town abides either way.

The city sprawls vast and indifferent, a concrete labyrinth where dwellings and commerce intermingle without pattern or purpose. Glass towers rise like ancient monoliths between squat buildings housing eateries and shops, their neon signs burning against the perpetual haze. The streets pulse with a ceaseless parade of humanity moving between corporate bastions and small storefronts that cling to existence like desert flowers in cracked pavement.

The parks stand as green islands in the urban waste, where mothers shepherd their young across worn paths while old men sit motionless on weathered benches watching nothing. The people here are a patchwork of tribes, each carrying their histories like invisible wounds. The rainbow folk claim their territory alongside black-clad Orthodox Jews, while scattered remnants of the fallen Soviet empire drift through the streets speaking in tongues of the steppes.

Beyond the immediate borders lie other enclaves - Korea town, China town, Little Armenia - each a world contained within walls of language and custom. Ten miles might as well be a hundred in this maze of steel and exhaust where two hours can vanish crossing what a crow would traverse in minutes. Nobody walks. They sit sealed in their vehicles like ancient mariners in iron ships, drifting through seas of brake lights that stretch endless into the smog-stained horizon.

The city devours itself and grows, sprouting new towers from its own decay. The people watch and curse the coming of more people, more machines, more metal boxes to house the endless tide of humanity. Houses squat between the towers, some grand, some humble, some split like cells into duplexes where families stack upon families. They stand as testaments to older dreams, when people knew their neighbors and children played in streets not yet choked with cars and fear.

Those days are gone now. The community exists only in memory, like smoke from a dead fire. The children who once played in these streets have grown and gone, leaving only ghosts of laughter that echo in empty yards where strange faces peer from windows, unknowing and unknown.

Where is it all at, she said. The corn stretched out before them like a yellow sea touching the rim of the world. This is all there is, he said. He knew the emptiness would shake her. She'd come from somewhere else. Somewhere where food came easy and streets were paved and lit. She'd never seen the vastness that was rural Ohio laid bare before her like this.

They drove on. The macadam road narrow and black cutting through the endless fields like a wound. Past the old quarry now full of dark water that reflected nothing back. Then the houses began. Brick and stucco dwellings set back from the road, each on its own plot of land tended with a kind of desperate pride. In spring the flowers came. Store-bought things in neat rows and the native trees changing their clothes with each turn of the season. The driveways held German cars, their surfaces gleaming like wet stone in the midday sun.

The Korean lived there too. An old doctor who'd lost some piece of himself to time. He rode his green machine in endless circles, singing songs no one knew the words to, his voice carrying over the mower's drone like some strange prayer. The neighbors watched him and smiled and shook their heads but he paid them no mind.

Past his place was home. Geese gathered in the side yard where the little terrier gave futile chase. Behind the house ran the creek that fed the quarry, its voice mixing with the bullfrogs and the distant lowing of cattle. Across a bridge built by hand lay a wild place. Trees and herbs and flowers that no one had planted grew there in profusion. This was where the children came. Where they built their wooden castles in the trees and stalked imaginary prey through the undergrowth.

Winter came hard to that place. The green world died and the trees stood like hanged men against the grey sky. But sometimes in the night the snow would come and transform everything. The yard would fill with the shapes of angels where his sister had lain and snowmen rose up like pale sentinels. The children built their fortifications then, packing snow into walls, gathering ammunition. They were warriors in a white world, fighting battles that meant everything and nothing at all. Just children in their own kingdom where time had no meaning and the future was as distant as the stars.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it.
